In our opinion that antidote is trace minerals and vitamins. The academical research shows that the use of metal-based products as an antimicrobial, is not new science, it is only forgotten science. Maybe paraphrasing Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes might be in order - When you have eliminated the impossible (trying over and over to create new antibiotics that just aren’t working), whatever remains (a new-old metal-based approach), however improbable, must be the truth. For Interest's Sake The operating company’s name, "Stoigela", is derived from a combination of Greek and Latin words, conveying the connotation "Elements of Life". The product range, "Zoilevium", is also derived from a combination of Greek and Latin words, signifying "New discoveries are the Essence of Life." General well-being implies a situation where one is generally “not sick”. The human body does however seem to be a target-rich environment for attacks from sources, foreign and/or domestic, so to speak. Bacteria, viruses, pathogens, cancers, autoimmune diseases, Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, dementia, and many other “enemies” are constantly looking for ways to attack our bodies. Our only natural defence against these attacks is our immune system. The immune system performs a vital role in protecting our bodies from harmful substances, like germs and cell changes that could make you ill. Without an immune system, we would have no way of fighting harmful pathogens that enter our bodies from the outside or harmful changes that occur inside our bodies.1 Main Tasks of the Immune System The main tasks of the body’s immune system are:1 to fight disease-causing pathogens like bacteria, viruses, parasites, or fungi, to recognize and neutralize harmful substances from the environment, and to fight disease-causing changes in the body, such as cancer cells. The Covid-19 outbreak was so widespread and devastating that it highlighted how vulnerable we are to attacks from such pathogens. To make things worse, the new generation of pathogens (for our purposes specifically bacteria and viruses), are becoming more and more resistant to conventional medicines and antibiotics. This is becoming so prevalent that these pathogens have earned the nickname of super-bugs. This drug resistance is referred to as antimicrobial resistance or AMR.2 Where Covid-19 is estimated to have claimed close to 7 million lives to date (February 2024), AMR claimed around 5 million lives in 2019 alone and is projected to potentially claim up to 10 million lives annually by 2050, and this figure is already starting to look low3, 4, 5, 6, 7, . Joshi says that, next to climate change, AMR is the most urgent global healthcare challenge the human species is facing.9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, So why is the discussion about AMR and immune systems important? Well, because one factor jeopardising our general well-being is the impact of AMR on our health. Case in point being Covid-19 or stubborn infections that just won’t respond to antibiotics. A second factor in our general well-being is the resilience of our immune systems. The stronger our immune systems are, the better they can protect us against constant attacks from harmful pathogens. This dual risk factor reasoning prompted the development of the Zoilevium product range. The approach was based on the following logic: If the immune system can be boosted, it will be beneficial to our general well-being, and If tenacious, drug-resistant pathogens can be combatted, general well-being can be improved. IBD According to the Crohn’s & Colitis Foundation,45 irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD with main types being Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative Colitis) are two distinct gastrointestinal disorders. The Mayo Clinic46 describes Crohn's disease as a type of IBD which causes swelling of the tissues (inflammation) in the digestive tract. This can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhoea, fatigue, weight loss and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. The most debilitating thing about Crohn’s disease is that it is believed that there is no known cure.46 The National Health Service (NHS) in Great Britain describes Crohn's disease as a “lifelong condition”.47 The best that the medical fraternity can do is to try and reduce the symptoms and hope for periods of remission where patients can try and lead a semi-normal life. The Zoilevium PureGut IBD & IBS Support explained in 3-steps. Step 1: What causes Crohn’s disease? To understand how Zoilevium PureGut can assist with IBS-related issues, we first need to try and figure out what causes Crohn’s disease. It turns out that nobody really knows. The best anyone can do is speculate. Typical answers you might find when researching the subject are: “The exact cause of Crohn's disease remains unknown.”45 “Doctors aren’t sure what causes Crohn's disease.”48 and, “There’s no known cause of Crohn’s disease.”49 It is extremely difficult to treat something you don’t know the cause of. How do you treat “something” if you don’t know what that “something” is? The best one can then do is treat the symptoms, because you can’t treat what you can’t identify. How do you solve a problem if you don’t know what the problem is? This is exactly what is happening with the current treatments of Crohn’s disease. Symptoms are being treated to alleviate discomfort, but the problem is never addressed and eradicated. Some of the best guesses as to the cause of Crohn’s disease are: A weakened immune system (the body's defence against infection) may lead to bacteria in the digestive tract which may cause the body’s immune system to attack healthy cells in the digestive system (this is called an autoimmune disease).47, 49 Key take-aways: Bacteria and immune system. Heredity. Crohn's disease is more common in people who have family members with the disease, so genes may play a role.46 A previous stomach bug which may open the door for other bacteria which may cause Crohn’s. Key take-away: Bacteria. An abnormal balance of gut bacteria.47 The use of antibiotics may disturb the normal bacterial ecosystem, which in turn may open the door to bad bacteria which may cause Crohn’s. Key take-away: Bacteria. At closer analysis, it seems that 3 of the 4 potential causes lean towards some or other bacterial involvement. Maybe this observation can bring us closer to a tenable answer as to a potential cause to be addressed when supporting and complimenting a normal treatment regime. Step 2: A closer look at potential bacterial candidates Based on the information gained in Step 1, let’s take a closer look at some suspicious bacteria that might be a source of concern. Mycobacterium avium paratuberculosis (MAP): MAP is a bacterial parasite that has long been considered to be a potential cause of Crohn's disease.48, 50, 51 Evidence in support of the hypothesis that MAP is a causative agent for Crohn's disease was reported as far back as the 1980’s. A study performed by Patterson et al (2021) found that there was evidence that MAP is highly associated with Crohn’s disease.52 Clostridioides (clostridium) difficile (c. diff): C. diff is an anaerobic gram-positive, spore-forming, bacterium that causes intestinal diseases varying from mild diarrhoea to severe colitis.51 C. diff infection (CDI) is a leading health concern worldwide.49 C. diff is responsible for 20% - 30% of cases of antibiotic-associated diarrhoea and 50% - 75% of cases of antibiotic associated colitis.51 IBD has been found to be associated with C. diff. People most often get C. diff infection after taking antibiotics that killed off other, helpful bacteria.49 This allows C. diff to spread quickly. C. diff is very hard to kill. They are resistant to heat, acid and many antibiotics and disinfectants.49 Although it is still not clear whether C. diff is a cause of IBD or a consequence of the inflammatory state in the intestinal environment, it is generally accepted that C. diff is somehow involved in Crohn’s disease.51 Antibiotic and other treatments: Antibiotic use can have several negative effects on the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). Antibiotic use may disrupt the normal bacterial ecosystem and thereby trigger new infections such as C. diff.54 Step 3: Why Zoilevium PureGut may be an effective support system. Zoilevium PureGut has the properties of a broad spectrum, inorganic, metallo-antibiotic. This means that it is a mineral-based antimicrobial compound produced by using bioinorganic chemistry.32, 42, 43 The value of minerals to our health is common knowledge and not disputed.
